revision.text:
{{Infobox Network |network_name = Aora |network_logo = [[File:Aora TV Logo.svg|200px|]] |country = [[Indonesia]] |network_type = [[Satellite Television]] |owner = [[Karyamegah Adijaya|PT Karyamegah Adijaya]] |key_people = Rini M. Soemarno, Ongki P. Soemarno, Sugiono Wiyono |launch_date = August 7, 2008 |closed_date = March 23, 2015 |founder = Rini M. Soemarno, Ongki P. Soemarno |motto = "Asyiknya 24 Jam" |past_names = Citra TV (2005-2008)
Astro Nusantara (2006-2008) |replaced _by_names = [[K-Vision]] |subsid = [[Foxtel]] |website = [http://www.aora.tv www.aora.tv] }} '''Aora''' is an [[Indonesia]]n [[direct broadcast satellite|direct broadcast]] [[satellite television|satellite]] [[pay television]] company that is operated by [[Karyamegah Adijaya|PT Karyamegah Adijaya]] and is owned by Rini M. Soemarno, Ongki P. Soemarno and join at dormant period Sugiono Wiyono. It started its nationwide broadcast in the beginning of August 2008 with an initial 10 channels, highlighting the [[2008 Summer Olympics]]. Four of the channels were dedicated to Olympic coverage. Aora earned the exclusive broadcasting rights to the 2008 Olympics exclusively for Indonesia.[http://www.kontan.co.id/index.php/Nasional/news/681/Aora_TV_Menyemarakkan_Pasar_Teve_Berbayar Aora TV Menyemarakkan Pasar Teve Berbayar] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080830060549/http://www.kontan.co.id/index.php/Nasional/news/681/Aora_TV_Menyemarakkan_Pasar_Teve_Berbayar |date=August 30, 2008 }}, ''Kontan Online'', August 7, 2008 Still in August 2008, Aora TV won the sole rights in Indonesia to broadcast the [[2008–09 Premier League|2008–09 season]] of the [[Premier League]] and offered a new, 12-channel package service which included [[ESPN]] and [[STAR Sports]], which contains the Premier League content. This allows Aora subscribers to watch, in full, the 370 Premier League matches of the 2008/09 season, including preview shows and weekly highlights.[http://www.detiksport.com/sepakbola/read/2008/08/18/182313/990460/72/liga-inggris-resmi-di-aora-tv Liga Inggris Resmi di Aora TV], ''detiksport'', August 18, 2008 The Premier League broadcast rights were then expired just few hours before the start of the 2009/2010 season, that forced Aora to replace both channels with [[GOALTV|Goal TV 1]] and [[GOALTV|Goal TV 2]] effective on August 15, 2009. At the same time, Aora also added several new channels into its channels lineup. Due to no exclusive Premier League matches again, Aora TV loss a lot of the subscribers and at end of 2009 Aora TV discontinued all of the broadcast followed by curtailment of 90 percent of the employees. In January 2010 Aora TV re-broadcast, but not as Premium/Exclusive Pay TV as before. At the current Aora TV try as medium to low income market with the lowest subscription fee Rp.59,000 (around $7) per month. In Q3 2011, Aora launched "Aora HD", an HD programming consisting of HBO HD, Star Movies HD, Discovery HD World, NGC HD, ASN, ESPN HD, FoodNetwork HD, Cartoon Network HD, HBO Hits HD and KompasTV HD. Fees are only for decoder rental which goes for Rp.99,000. (approximately US$11) per month.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}} On March 23, 2015, Aora's service was closed for information via email that is limited to active subscribers and Aora services will be presented in a new format requiring re-registration for customers who still want to resume service. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.aora.tv Official Site] {{TV Providers in Indonesia}} {{CATV Africa, Asia, and Oceania}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aora Tv}} [[Category:Satellite television]] [[Category:Television in Indonesia]]

'''Fedustria''' is the [[Belgium|Belgian]] [[non profit]] federation of the [[textile]], [[wood]] and [[furniture]] industry. It was founded on 20 December 2006 in [[Ghent]] and is the successor of ''Febeltex'' and ''Febelhout''. The organization represents a turnover of 12 billion Euro employs more than 60,000 people in 2,700 companies in Belgium. Fedustria is also the parent organization of the [[Belgian Linen | Belgian Flax and Linen Association]].
==Textile companies== ** To be expanded * [[Associated Weavers]] * [[Beaulieu International Group]] * [[DOMO Group]] * [[Libeco]] * [[Seyntex]] * [[Sioen Industries]]
==Wood and furniture companies== ** To be expanded
==See also== * [[Agoria]] * [[Federation of Belgian Enterprises]] * [[Future Textiles and Clothing]] (EU)
==Sources== * [http://www.nieuwsblad.be/Article/Detail.aspx?ArticleID=B360202061222 Febeltex en Febelhout fuseren tot Fedustria] (Dutch) * [http://www.hetvolk.be/Article/Detail.aspx?articleID=dmf22122006_028 Febeltex en Febelhout fuseren tot Fedustria] (Dutch)
==External links== * [http://www.fedustria.be/ Fedustria]

France
Germany | language = | budget = | gross = | screenplay = William Klein | cinematography = [[Pierre Lhomme]]
William Klein | editing = Jacqueline Meppiel
Jean Ravel | music = }} '''''Festival panafricain d’Alger 1969''''' is a 1969 documentary film. == Synopsis == ''Algiers Pan-African Festival'' is a documentary shot in 1969 during the first edition of the Festival. [[William Klein (photographer)|William Klein]] follows the preparations of this "Opera from the Third World", the rehearsals, and the concerts. He blends images of interviews made with writers and advocates of the freedom movements with stock images, thus allowing him to touch on such matters as colonialism, [[neocolonialism]], colonial exploitation, the struggles and battles of the revolutionary movements for independence, and African culture. == References == {{RefFCAT|482}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|1492837}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Festival panafricain d'Alger 1969}} [[Category:Creative Commons-licensed documentary films]] [[Category:Algerian documentary films]] [[Category:French documentary films]] [[Category:German documentary films]] [[Category:Algerian films]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:West German films]] [[Category:1960s documentary films]] [[Category:1969 films]] [[Category:Documentary films about African resistance to colonialism]] [[Category:Films directed by William Klein]] {{Algeria-film-stub}} {{1960s-France-film-stub}} {{1960s-Germany-film-stub}} {{hist-documentary-film-stub}}

The '''flying geese paradigm''' ('''FGP''') is a view of Japanese scholars upon the technological development in [[Southeast Asia]] viewing [[Japan]] as a leading power. It was developed in the 1930s, but gained wider popularity in the 1960s after its author [[Kaname Akamatsu]] published his ideas in the ''[[Journal of Developing Economies]]''.<ref>Tausch, Arno, The Hallmarks of Crisis: A New Center-Periphery Perspective on Long Cycles (July 16, 2013). {{DOI|10.2139/ssrn.2294324}}</ref>
==Akamatsu’s third flying geese paradigm==
[[image:V-formation.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Geese]] in [[V formation]]]] Akamatsu’s third flying geese paradigm (FGP) is a model for international division of labor in East Asia based on dynamic [[comparative advantage]]. The paradigm postulated that Asian nations will catch up with the West as a part of a regional hierarchy where the production of [[Commodification|commoditized]] goods would continuously move from the more advanced countries to the less advanced ones. The underdeveloped nations in the region could be considered to be "aligned successively behind the advanced industrial nations in the order of their different stages of growth in a wild-geese-flying pattern."<ref>Ozawa, T. (2005), 9</ref> The lead goose in this pattern is Japan itself, the second-tier of nations consisted of the [[Newly industrialized country|newly industrializing economies]] (South Korea, Singapore, Taiwan and Hong Kong). After these two groups come the main [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations|ASEAN]] countries: Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Finally the least developed major nations in the region: China, Vietnam, the Philippines, etc. make up the rear guard in the formation.<ref>Kasahara S. (2004), 2–13</ref>
The main driver in the model is the "leader's imperative for internal restructuring"<ref>Kasahara S. (2004), 10</ref> due to increasing labor costs. As the comparative advantages (on a global scale) of the "lead goose" causes it to shift further and further away from labor-intensive production to more capital-intensive activities it sheds its low-productivity production to nations further down in the hierarchy in a pattern that then reproduces itself between the countries in the lower tiers. The impulse for development always comes from the top tier causing many to label the FGP a top-down model.<ref>Kasahara S. (2004), 9–10</ref> The FGP has proved to be a useful tool when describing the regional production patterns in East Asia as industries such as the textile industry has left not only Japan – the most advanced East Asian nation – but also, at a later point, South Korea, and Taiwan etc. These second tier nations have now firmly established themselves in for instance the automotive industry and advanced production of [[consumer electronics]] and the like.
The vehicle for [[technology transfer]] is where Akamatsu’s framework is least developed. He does however suggest that the demonstration effect of international trade plays an important part as well as the "animal spirit of the entrepreneurs" in developing countries. More recently, modified versions of the FGP – such as the one presented in Ozawa (1995) – stress the importance of transnational firms in this area.<ref>Kasahara S. (2004), 12</ref>
Regarding the internal order of nations within the model, Akamatsu did not consider the relative positions to be permanently fixed but could rather be seen as inherently unstable. This idea is most likely connected to the memories of the Japanese development in the late 19th century when it catapulted itself from a technological backwater to a mature industrial powerhouse. Other scholars, however, have emphasized the stability and harmony of the clustered growth envisaged in the FGP implying it would be difficult for a nation to shift from one tier to another.<ref>Kasahara S. (2004), 12–13</ref>
==The relevance of Akamatsu's paradigm==
As has been shown recently,<ref>Tausch, Arno, The Hallmarks of Crisis: A New Center-Periphery Perspective on Long Cycles (July 16, 2013). {{DOI|10.2139/ssrn.2294324}}</ref> Akamatsu's theory emphasizes the differentiation of the world economy, which leads to the rapid diffusion of new techniques to rising industrial nations, which starts with the import of new commodities by these nations. In time, techniques and capital goods are imported as well, and homogenous industries are being established. The uniformization of both industry and agriculture gave rise to the fierce and conflictive competition between Europe, the United States and Japan in the last quarter of the 19th Century. When an innovation occurs in some industry in an advanced nation, investment is concentrated there, causing a rise in the trade cycle. Innovation leads to an increase in exports, and the nation’s prosperity creates and increases the import of raw materials and foodstuffs.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/911206248|title=Great divergence and great convergence : a global perspective|last=V.,|first=Korotaev, A.|date=2015|publisher=Springer|isbn=9783319363660|oclc=911206248}}</ref> Akamatsu sees a counter-movement in other parts of the world, centered on the rising production of gold, which, according to him, leads to an increase in effective demand and further stimulates exports of the innovating nation. In that way, world production and trade expand, prices increase and a worldwide rise in the long-term trade cycle results.
However, innovations spread from the innovating nations to other nations, leading to the development of industries in those countries, with the result of a conflictive relationship with the industries of the innovating nation. Exports of the innovating nation become stagnant, and on the world level, there is a tendency towards [[overproduction]], prices turn downwards, and the rates of growth of production and trade fall. The first, rising [[A-phase]] of the [[Kondratiev cycle]] will be according to Akamatsu a period of differentiation in the world economic structure, while the “falling period” or [[B-phase]] of the [[Kondratiev cycle]] will, Akamatsu argues, coincide with a process of uniformization in world economic structure.
For Akamatsu, the characteristic structure of the Center-Periphery relationship is characterized by the fact that the underdeveloped nation will export primary products and will import industrial goods for consumption. Later on, an underdeveloped nation will attempt to produce goods which were hitherto imported, first in the field of consumer goods, and later on in the area of capital goods. As the fourth stage of the process, the underdeveloped nation will attempt to export capital goods. There will be a tendency of “advanced” differentiation in the world economy, however, because the capital goods industries in advanced nations will still advance further, giving rise to “extreme differences of comparative costs”. The wild-geese flying pattern will include three sub-patterns: the first is the sequence of imports – domestic production – exports. The second will be the sequence from consumer goods to capital goods and from crude and simple articles to complex and refined articles. The third will be the alignment from the advanced nations to backward nations according to their stages of growth.
However, there is a darker and more somber nature of these cycles as well – the condition of discrepancy will be met, Akamatsu argues, by means of imports, leading to discrepancies in the balance of payments, and the pressure to increase exports of primary products to improve the balance. Discrepancies will also lead to a shift of production away from domestic industries in the underdeveloped country towards the export sector; leading, in the end, also to problems of excessive supply capacities in the underdeveloped country etc.
At the end of the day, Akamatsu believes in a Hegelian dialectic between the three basic discrepancies, characterizing the process of development: the discrepancy of development, the cyclical discrepancy between the rich and the poor countries, and the structural discrepancy.
== References == {{reflist}}

''International Organization'' 38#1 (1984): 1-40. * Grinin, L., Korotayev, A. and Tausch A. (2016) ''Economic Cycles, Crises, and the Global Periphery''. Springer International Publishing, Heidelberg, New York, Dordrecht, London, {{ISBN|978-3-319-17780-9}} * Hatch, Walter F. (2010) ''Asia's Flying Geese: How Regionalization Shapes Japan'' (2010). *Kasahara S. (2004): The Flying Geese Paradigm: A Critical study of Its Application to East Asian Regional Development, United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, Discussion Paper # 169, April. *Ozawa, T. (2005): ''Institutions, Industrial Upgrading, and Economic Performance in Japan – The ‘Flying-Geese Paradigm of Catch-up Growth''. Northampton, Massachusetts: Edward Elgar Publishing. *Terry, E. (2002): ''How Asia got Rich –Japan, China, and the Asian Miracle'' Armonk, New York: M.E. Sharp Publishing. *Tausch A. (2015): The Hallmarks of Crisis. A New Center-periphery Perspective on Long Economic Cycles. Kondratieff Waves Almanac, 2015: 18-29. Volgograd: Uchitel Publishing House (http://www.sociostudies.org/almanac/k_waves/)

It made its first broadcast on January 1, 1988. ==Channel listing== All the following channels can be viewed in [[Guangzhou]] and [[Foshan]]. * [[Guangzhou Television main channel]] ({{lang|zh-Hans-CN|广州台}} or {{lang|zh-Hans-CN|广州电视台}}) * [[Guangzhou News channel]] ({{lang|zh-Hans-CN|广州新闻台}}) * [[Guangzhou sports channel]] ({{lang|zh-Hans-CN|广州竞赛台}}) * [[Guangzhou Drama channel]] ({{lang|zh-Hans-CN|广州影视影视台}}) * [[Guangzhou live channel]] ({{lang|zh-Hans-CN|广州生活台}}) * [[Guangzhou Economic channel]] ({{lang|zh-Hans-CN|广州经济台}}) * [[Guangzhou Children channel]] ({{lang|zh-Hans-CN|广州少儿台}}) * [[Guangzhou Shopping channel]] ({{lang|zh-Hans-CN|广州购物台}}) * [[Guangzhou Mobile channel]] ({{lang|zh-Hans-CN|广州移动频道}}) == See also == * [[Guangdong Television]] * [[Guangzhou TV Tower]] * [[Southern Television Guangdong|TVS]] {{Chinese broadcast television}} [[Category:Chinese television networks]] [[Category:Television stations in China]] [[Category:Media in Guangzhou]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 1988]] {{PRChina-tv-stub}}

The satellite features 4 × [[SPT-100]] [[plasma propulsion engine]]s. This mission also carried a small (90 kg) technology demonstration satellite called [[Payload Orbital Delivery System Satellite]] (PODSat), which was deployed from its mothership when still in a sub-geostationary transfer orbit.{{cite web|last1=Krebs|first1=Gunter| title=PODSAT 1| url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/podsat.htm| website=space.skyrocket.de|publisher=Gunter's Space Page| accessdate=9 March 2018}} == Photogallery == Hispasat 30W-6 Mission (39951085264).jpg Hispasat 30W-6 Mission (39951085474).jpg Hispasat 30W-6 Mission (40660917561).jpg Hispasat 30W-6 Mission (25790223907).jpg ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Space program of Spain}} {{Falcon rocket launches}} {{Orbital launches in 2018}} [[Category:Satellites of Spain]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2018]] [[Category:2018 in Spain]] [[Category:Satellites using the SSL 1300 bus]] [[Category:SpaceX commercial payloads]] [[Category:Communications satellites in geostationary orbit]] {{Spain-spacecraft-stub}}

The station features topics ranging from customs and traditions to social-economic development, global and social trends, health and nutrition as well as agriculture and enables local entertainers to showcase their talents with the station playing 80% Sabahan songs.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyexpress.com.my/news.cfm?NewsID=105791|title=New radio station to debut|publisher=[[Daily Express (Malaysia)|Daily Express]]|date=12 January 2016|accessdate=13 January 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160113142817/http://www.dailyexpress.com.my/news.cfm?NewsID=105791|archivedate=13 January 2016|deadurl=no}} It can also be heard from [[Kuala Penyu]] to [[Kota Belud]] and plans to expand transmission to other parts of Sabah in future.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/metro/community/2016/01/13/new-radio-station-to-play-sabah-songs/|title=New radio station to play Sabah songs|author=Stephanie Lee|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]|date=13 January 2016|accessdate=13 January 2016}} == Announcers == The current radio announcers are: * Janrywine Lusin * Queenera Kitingan (Nera [[Akademi Fantasia (season 9)|AF9]]) * Velvet Aduk (Velvet [[Akademi Fantasia (season 4)|AF4]]) * Gregory Giting * Nizhamul Hayat == References == == External links == * {{official|http://www.kupikupifm.my/}} {{Radio stations of Malaysia|Companies}} {{Asia-radio-station-stub}} [[Category:Radio stations in Malaysia]] [[Category:2016 establishments in Malaysia]] {{Coord missing|Malaysia}}

Nature and Fisheries]] |term_start2 = 9 June 1999 |term_end2 = 22 July 2002 |primeminister2 = [[Wim Kok]] |predecessor2 = [[Klaas de Vries (Labour Party)|Klaas de Vries]] (''Ad interim'') |successor2 = [[Cees Veerman]] |office3 = [[Member of the European Parliament]]
for the [[Netherlands]] |term_start3 = 19 July 1994 |term_end3 = 8 June 1999 |parliamentarygroup3= [[Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe group|European Liberal Democrat
and Reform Party Group]] |office4 = [[List of ambassadors of the European Union|Ambassador of the European Union to Japan]] |term_start4 = 1 December 1982 |term_end4 = 1 January 1987 |predecessor4 = [[Leslie Fielding]] |successor4 = [[Dries van Agt]] |office5 = [[Leader of the Democrats 66]] |term_start5 = 8 September 1982 |term_end5 = 10 November 1982 |predecessor5 = [[Jan Terlouw]] |successor5 = [[Maarten Engwirda]] |office6 = [[Parliamentary leader]] in the
[[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|House of Representatives]] |term_start6 = 11 September 1981 |term_end6 = 10 November 1982 |predecessor6 = [[Jan Terlouw]] |successor6 = [[Maarten Engwirda]] |parliamentarygroup6= [[Democrats 66]] |office7 = [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|Member of the House of Representatives]] |term_start7 = 8 June 1977 |term_end7 = 10 November 1982 |parliamentarygroup7= [[Democrats 66]] |office8 = [[List of Ministers of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands#List of State Secretaries for Foreign Affairs|State Secretary for Foreign Affairs]] |term_start8 = 11 May 1973 |term_end8 = 8 September 1977 |alongside8 = [[Pieter Kooijmans]] |primeminister8 = [[Joop den Uyl]] |predecessor8 = [[Tjerk Westerterp]] |successor8 = [[Durk van der Mei]] |birthname = Laurens Jan Brinkhorst |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1937|03|18|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Zwolle]], [[Netherlands]] |death_date = |death_place = |nationality = [[Netherlands|Dutch]] |party = [[Democrats 66]] (from 1966) |spouse = {{marriage|Jantien Heringa|26 August 1960}} |children = [[Princess Laurentien of the Netherlands|Princess Laurentien]] (born 1966)
1 other daughter |residence = [[Leiden]], [[Netherlands]] |alma_mater = [[Leiden University]]
([[Bachelor of Laws]], [[Master of Laws]])
[[Columbia University]]
([[Bachelor of Social Science]], [[Master of Social Science]]) |occupation = [[Politician]] · [[Diplomat]] · [[Civil service|Civil servant]] · [[Jurist]] · [[Lawyer]] · [[Legal education|Legal educator]] · [[Research]]er · [[Board of directors|Nonprofit director]] · [[Lobbying|Lobbyist]] · [[Activism|Activist]] · [[Author]] · [[Professor]] |signature = |website = }} '''Laurens Jan Brinkhorst''' (born 18 March 1937) is a retired [[Netherlands|Dutch]] politician and diplomat of the [[Democrats 66]] (D66) party. ==Early life and education== Laurens-Jan Brinkhorst was born in the city of [[Zwolle]]. After getting his high school diploma (''gymnasium-B-diploma'' in Dutch) he studied law at the [[University of Leiden]] (''Rijksuniversiteit Leiden'' in Dutch), where he obtained his [[Master of Laws|LL.M.]] degree in 1959. He received also an [[Master of Arts|M.A.]] degree in Public Law and Government from [[Columbia University]] in [[New York City]]. Afterwards he worked at [[Shearman & Sterling]] in [[New York City]]. ==Personal life== On 26 August 1960, Brinkhorst married Jantien Heringa (born 2 February 1935 in [[Voorburg]]), daughter of Ewardus Heringa ([[Den Haag]], 14 November 1904 - [[Den Haag]], 30 November 1988) and wife (m. [[Utrecht (province)|Utrecht]], 4 August 1930) Petronela Johanna Roskam ([[Utrecht (province)|Utrecht]], 20 August 1905 - [[Den Haag]], 19 December 1991). Brinkhorst and Heringa are the parents of Marius Brinkhorst (born 9 February 1964) and the Dutch princess [[Princess Laurentien of the Netherlands|Laurentien Brinkhorst]] (born 25 May 1966), who married [[Prince Constantijn of the Netherlands|Prince Constantijn]] in 2001.[http://www.geneall.net/W/per_page.php?id=131916 Geneall] ==Career in politics and academia== From 1962, and from 1965 as a director, he worked at the Europe-institute at the [[university of Leiden|Rijksuniversiteit Leiden]] where he became a Reader (Lector) in 1965 as well. During the period 1967-1973 he was Professor of European Law at the University of Groningen ([[Rijksuniversiteit Groningen]] in Dutch). On 11 May 1973, he became Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs in the Cabinet of [[Joop den Uyl|Den Uyl]]. In 1977 he was again a member of the Second Chamber of the Dutch parliament for D66 and in 1981 became the leader of his party in parliament. From 1983-1987 he was Ambassador of the European Community in [[Japan]]. In 1987 he became a correspondent of the [[Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences]].{{cite web|author= |url=http://knaw.nl/en/members/correspondents/3948 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170904200752/http://knaw.nl/en/members/correspondents/3948 |title=Laurens Jan Brinkhorst |publisher=Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences |date= |archive-date=4 September 2017}} Between 1987 and 1994 Brinkhorst continued his service at the European Commission as Director-General for Environmental Affairs and Nuclear Safety. In 1994 Brinkhorst became a member of the [[European Parliament]], serving there until 1999. Brinkhorst was also a member of the ''Provinciale Staten'' (the provincial parliament) of the province of [[Groningen (province)|Groningen]] for D66, a member of the board of advice of the World Resources Institute in [[Washington DC]], a member of the board of governors of the ''Nederlands Economisch Instituut'' (Dutch Economical Institute), a professor by special appointment of international environmental law at the University of Leiden, a member of the Board of Directors of the Salzburg Seminar, a member of the Board of Directors of the International Institute of Sustainable Development, and a professor (on a temporary basis) of international [[environmental law]] at the University of [[Lausanne]]. On 8 June 1999 he became the minister of agriculture, environmental control and fishery in the cabinet [[Second cabinet of Wim Kok|Kok-II]]. Afterwards (2002) he became an Adviser of European Affairs at NautaDulith in [[Brussels]] and was awarded a professorship in transnational and European Governance at the University of [[Tilburg]]. After the electoral defeat of D66 he became a minister of economic affairs in the [[second Balkenende cabinet]]. Brinkhorst, as well as [[Alexander Pechtold]], resigned from his minister post after the second Balkenende [[second Balkenende cabinet#2006 cabinet crisis|cabinet]] lost the confidence of parliament on 29 June 2006. The next day, Balkenende offered the resignation of the full cabinet to the [[Beatrix of the Netherlands|Dutch Queen]]. From 1 November 2006 to 1 November 2011, Brinkhorst was a [[full professor]] at the [[Leiden University]]. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== ;Official * {{nl icon}} [http://www.parlement.com/id/vg09llg009z1/l_j_laurens_jan_brinkhorst Mr. L.J. (Laurens Jan) Brinkhorst] Parlement & Politiek {{s-start}} {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before=[[Jan Terlouw]]|rows=2}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Parliamentary leader]] of the
[[Democrats 66]] in the

{{Infobox official post |post = Head of Government |body = the
Principality of Andorra |insignia = Coat of Arms of the high authorities of Andorra.svg |insigniasize = 125px |insigniacaption = [[Coat of arms of Andorra]] |native_name = Cap de Govern del Principat d'Andorra |image = Antoni Martí (2011).jpg |imagesize = 165px |incumbent = [[Antoni Martí]] |incumbentsince = 1 April 2015 |style = |residence = |appointer = [[General Council of Andorra]] |termlength = Four years, renewable |formation = 8 January 1982 |succession = |inaugural = [[Òscar Ribas Reig]] |deputy = |salary = |website = [http://www.govern.ad www.govern.ad] }} {{Politics of Andorra}} The '''Head of Government of the Principality of Andorra''' ({{Lang-ca|Cap de Govern del Principat d'Andorra}}), alternatively known as the Prime Minister of Andorra, is the chief executive of the government of [[Andorra]]. They are appointed by the [[General Council (Andorra)|General Council]]. The position was created in 1982 after constitutional reforms separated the executive and legislative power. [[Òscar Ribas Reig]] was elected as the country's first Head of Government on 4 January 1982.[[Dieter Nohlen|Nohlen D]] & Stöver P (2010) ''Elections in Europe: A data handbook'', p160 {{ISBN|978-3-8329-5609-7}} The current Head of Government is [[Antoni Martí]], who has been in office since 31 March 2015. ==Heads of Government of Andorra (1982–present)== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- align=center bgcolor=#ebebeb !rowspan=2|№ !rowspan=2|Name

Amman, Jordan | slogan = A7la eza3a "The Best Station" | airdate = 20 March 2005 | frequency = 95.3 MHz | format = Arabic [[Pop music|pop]] station | power = 800 [[watt]]s | erp = 3 [[kilowatt]]s | owner = [[National Broadcast Ltd.]] | website = http://www.mazajfm.com/ }} '''Mazaj 95.3 FM''' is a privately owned [[radio station]] located in [[Amman]], [[Jordan]]. The station was established in 2005 and is owned by the National Broadcast Company, which was founded by Abu-Lughod Studios and [[Seagulls Broadcast]]. ==Format== The station focuses on giving its audience the latest [[Arabic pop music]] as well as popular [[Arabic]] hits played throughout the past decades. ==External links== *[http://www.mazajfm.com/ Official website] {{Coord missing|Jordan}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mazaj 95.3 Fm}} [[Category:Radio stations in Jordan]] [[Category:Media in Amman]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 2005]] {{Asia-radio-station-stub}} {{Jordan-stub}}

{{Infobox television | show_name = Montra Lai Hong มนตราลายหงส์ | image = | caption = | show_name_2 = | genre = {{unbulleted list||[[Drama]]|[[Romance film|Romance]]}} | creator = Chonlumpi Brothers Company Limited | developer = | writer = {{unbulleted list|Satarat|Plaiseet}} | director = Chatchai Naksuriya,
Nathapong Wongkawiphairot | starring = {{unbulleted list|[[Warintorn Panhakarn]]|[[Maneerat Sricharoon]]|[[Natthaweeranuch Thongmee]]|[[Anuchit Sapanpong]]}} | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | country = [[Thailand]] | language = [[Thai language|Thai]] | num_episodes = 7 | executive_producer = | producer = {{unbulleted list|Suangsuda Cholumpi|Chunlawut Cholumpi}} | location = [[Thailand]] | camera = | runtime = 150 minutes | network = [[Channel 3 (Thailand)|Channel 3]] | picture_format = [[1080i]] ([[High-definition television|HDTV]]) 16:9 | audio_format = [[Channel 4|Channel 4 HD]] | first_aired = {{start date|2018|6|15}} | last_aired = {{end date|2018|6|29}} | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = {{unbulleted list|[[Matuphoom Haeng Huachai]] (2018)|[[Lom Phrai Pook Rak]] (2018)|[[Sen Son Kon Rak]] (2018)|[[Tai Peek Pak Sa]]}} (2018) | website = http://www.ch3thailand.com/ละครช่อง3/second/487/มนตราลายหงษ์.html | website_title = Montra Lai Hong on Thai TV 3 }} '''''Montra Lai Hong''''' ({{lang-th|มนตราลายหงส์}}) is a Thai romantic-drama TV series that aired on [[Channel 3 (Thailand)|Channel 3]]. It starred [[Warintorn Panhakarn]], [[Maneerat Sricharoon]], [[Natthaweeranuch Thongmee]] and [[Anuchit Sapanpong]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.ch3thailand.com/%E0%B8%A5%E0%B8%B0%E0%B8%84%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%8A%E0%B9%88%E0%B8%AD%E0%B8%873/second/487/%E0%B8%A1%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%95%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%A5%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%AB%E0%B8%87%E0%B8%A9%E0%B9%8C.html|title=My Hero วีรบุรุษสุดที่รัก : มนตราลายหงส์|last=|first=|date=|website=www.ch3thailand.com|language=th-TH|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.siamzone.com/drama/1491|title=My Hero วีรบุรุษสุดที่รัก ตอน มนตราลายหงส์|last=|first=|date=|website=SIAMZONE.COM|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} It's the second drama of project "''My hero''". == Plot == Patsakorn's father was a dance teacher and the owner of a school for poor children but he died since Patsakorn ([[Warintorn Panhakarn]]) was very young. Patsakorn inherited his father's talent and decided to open a dance school. There was an explosion at the opening and, as a result, his adoptive parents and his foster sister died. He blamed himself for their deaths and fell into depression. == Cast == === Main cast === * [[Warintorn Panhakarn]] as Teacher Patsakorn Wirayakan (Pat) * [[Maneerat Sricharoon]] as Waenploy (Ploy) * [[Natthaweeranuch Thongmee]] as Kwankamon Uthinthep (Khwan) * [[Anuchit Sapanpong]] as Thanat Detsahakun (Te) === Supporting cast === * [[Smithi Likhitmaskul]] as Nirut * [[Wanpiya Oamsinnoppakul]] as Chanthima * [[Wirakan Senitantikun]] as Kunkking * [[Kanokchat Manyaton]] as Chatchai  * [[Techin Pinchatri]] as Kuang * [[Chatchawan Phetwisit]] as Na * [[Chalit Fuangarom]] as Waenploy's granddad * [[Sattha Satthathip]] as Wirot === Guests === * [[Sinjai Plengpanich]] as Teacher Chanthra * [[Pakorn Chatborirak]] as Major Techat Wasutraphaisan (Ben) * [[Jaron Sorat]] as Itsara Ratchaphonkun * [[Pongsakorn Mettarikanon]] as Khong Thamdee * [[Louis Scott (actor)|Louis Scott]] as Akhin Nopprasit * [[Duanghathai Sathathip]] as Nid == References == == External links == * {{IMDb title|8765092|Montra Lai Hong}} * [http://www.ch3thailand.com/%E0%B8%A5%E0%B8%B0%E0%B8%84%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%8A%E0%B9%88%E0%B8%AD%E0%B8%873/second/487/%E0%B8%A1%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%95%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%A5%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%AB%E0%B8%87%E0%B8%A9%E0%B9%8C.html Montra Lai Hong] on Thai TV 3 * [https://www.siamzone.com/drama/1491 Montra Lai Hong] on Siamzone * [https://www.online-idol.com/2018/06/14/mantra-laihong-synopsis Montra Lai Hong's synopsis] on online-idol * [https://www.instagram.com/cholumpi_production/ Cholumpi Production] {{myheroseriesth}} [[Category:Thai television soap operas]] [[Category:2010s Thai television series]] [[Category:2018 Thai television series debuts]] [[Category:2018 Thai television series endings]] [[Category:Television shows set in Bangkok]] {{Thailand-tv-stub}}

{{About|the proposed television channel|the channel's owner|Raidió Teilifís Éireann}} {{Infobox TV channel | name = RTÉ Ireland | logofile = RTÉ logo.svg | logosize = 150px | logoalt = | logo2 = | launch = | closed date = | picture format = [[576i]] ([[16:9]] [[Standard-definition television|SDTV]]) | share = | share as of = | share source = | network = | owner = [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]] | slogan = | country = Ireland | language = English
Irish | broadcast area = United Kingdom, Worldwide (expected) | headquarters = [[Dublin]] | former names = | replaced names = | replaced by names = | sister names = [[RTÉ One]]
[[RTÉ Two]]
[[RTÉ News Now]]
[[RTÉjr]] | timeshift names = | web = http://www.rte.ie/ | terr serv 1 = | terr chan 1 = | sat serv 1 = | sat chan 1 = | cable serv 1 = | cable chan 1 = | sat radio serv 1 = | sat radio chan 1 = | adsl serv 1 = | adsl chan 1 = | online serv 1 = | online chan 1 = | 3gmobile serv 1 = }} '''RTÉ Ireland''' (lit. Raidió Teilifís Éireann Ireland = Radio Television Ireland Ireland) is the planned international television channel by [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland's]] public service broadcaster [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]] (RTÉ).{{cite web|url=http://static.rasset.ie/documents/news/rtestrategicplan-shortversion.pdf |title=Strategy 2012-2017 |publisher=RTÉ |date=2013-09-16 |accessdate=2013-09-16}} The channel will broadcast online at [[RTÉ.ie]], [[IPTV]] and on satellite in the United Kingdom. The channel is expected to offer programmes from [[RTÉ One]] and [[RTÉ Two|Two]], including education, drama, comedy, music, news and current affairs. This includes ''[[The All Ireland Talent Show]]'', ''[[Fair City]]'', ''[[Dragons' Den]]'' and ''[[The Late Late Show (Ireland)|The Late Late Show]]''. The [[Oireachtas]] (parliament) has passed legislation requiring that RTÉ supply international service to suit the needs of Irish citizens living abroad, along with other new digital RTÉ channels. ==History== The channel was initially to launch in Spring 2009 under the branding RTÉ International. The channel was expected to launch in the [[United Kingdom]] in March 2009. (RTÉ's domestic channels are already available on [[Freeview (UK)|Freeview]], [[Sky (UK and Ireland)|Sky]] and [[Virgin Media]] in [[Northern Ireland]], but not to [[Great Britain]], owing to rights restrictions.) There are also plans to launch the channel in North America and [[Central Europe]]. A similar service aired from 1996 until 2002 operated by a now-defunct cable and satellite channel, [[Tara Television]]. This channel was carried on [[Sky (UK and Ireland)|Sky]] in the United Kingdom and on a small number of cable television services. The channel was 75% owned by [[Liberty Global|UPC]], RTÉ owned the remaining 25%. It was claimed by RTÉ that the channel could not pay royalty payments due to RTÉ for their programming. Despite a last minute deal between [[Setanta Sports]] and [[Liberty Global|UPC]], Tara closed down, leaving Irish viewers in Britain without access to Irish television. Setanta then considered themselves creating a direct replacement channel carrying the best of RTÉ TV in Britain during 2004, but this did not materialise.[http://archives.tcm.ie/businesspost/2002/03/24/story5152728.asp]{{dead link|date=September 2013}} A [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrat]] councillor, of Irish extraction, Martin Curry, is seeking to have RTÉ International carried on the digital terrestrial television service, [[Freeview (UK)|Freeview]], if Sky removes its channels from Freeview, rather than allowing Sky to use the bandwidth for subscription television.{{cite web|last=Oatts |first=Joanne |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tech/news/a42678/sky-warns-cable-viewers-channels-may-go.html |title=Sky warns cable viewers channels may go |publisher=Digital Spy |date=2007-02-12 |accessdate=2013-09-16}} However, this is unlikely to happen as limited capacity on Freeview generally prevents the broadcasting of minority channels during main daytime/peak time hours.{{cn|date=January 2014}} On 17 March 2008, [[Eamon Ryan]] the [[Minister for Communications, Energy and Natural Resources|Minister for Communications]] announced the launch of RTÉ International under the new working title of Diaspora TV. On 4 June 2008 [[The Irish Post]] reported that the channel would not in fact be named Diaspora TV and would keep the RTÉ International name, they also added that the channel may be operational ahead of the previously scheduled launch date of 17 March 2009. {{cite web |url=http://www.irishpost.co.uk/news/story/?trs=qlojidoj&cat=news |title=RTÉ International: It’s coming soon! |publisher=[[The Irish Post]] |date=2008-06-04 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080618015432/http://www.irishpost.co.uk/news/story/?trs=qlojidoj&cat=news |archivedate=2008-06-18 }} On 2 November 2008, RTÉ postponed the planned launch, citing straitened financial circumstances. The broadcaster wrote to Eamon Ryan during October claiming that it would be “unwise” for it to continue with the plan. RTÉ said it intended to honour the commitment in the [[Broadcasting (Amendment) Act 2007|2007 Broadcasting Act]] and hoped to launch the station by the end of 2009. A spokeswoman for Eamon Ryan said the decision to postpone the launch of the channel was "a reflection of the financial realities in Ireland and worldwide". She said the minister is committed to the idea of RTÉ International and that it could be a "brilliant product" similar to [[BBC World News]]. {{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/ireland/article5063332.ece |title=RTÉ shelves UK launch |publisher=[[The Sunday Times]] |date=2008-11-02 | location=London | first=Mark | last=Tighe | accessdate=22 May 2010 }} In September 2013 RTÉ announced new plans to launch the channel in the United Kingdom under the working title of RTÉ Ireland, as part of their five-year strategic plan. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.rte.ie RTÉ] {{RTÉ Television}} {{Television in Ireland}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rte Ireland}} [[Category:External services (broadcasting)]] [[Category:Proposed television channels and networks]] [[Category:RTÉ television channels|Ireland]]

88.0 MHz ([[Nikšić]]) | format = [[Public radio|Public]] | power = | erp = | class = | callsign_meaning = | former_callsigns = | owner = [[RTCG|Radio Televizija Crne Gore (RTCG)]] | webcast = [http://radio.beotel.net:8008/listen.pls Slušaj uživo] | website = [http://www.rtcg.me/ www.rtcg.me] | affiliations = }} '''Radio Crne Gore''' is a radio station in [[Montenegro]]. It is part of [[RTCG|Radio Televizija Crne Gore]] (Radio-Television of Montenegro). Radio Crne Gore broadcasts from [[Podgorica]]. ==History== In 1949, Radio Titograd was formed. In 1963, RTV Titograd was established, making Radio Titograd a part of it. In 1990, Radio Titograd changed its name to ''Radio Crne Gore''. RTV Titograd eventually was renamed to [[RTCG|Radio Televizija Crne Gore]], making Radio Crna Gora a part of it ever since. ==Radio Montenegro Trophy== In 2014, [[Football Association of Montenegro]] altogether with Radio Montenegro founded Radio Montenegro Trophy, commemorating the 70th anniversary of the radio. The trophy is awarded to best scorer of the [[Montenegrin First League]]. ==External links== *[http://www.rtcg.me Official Site] {{coord missing|Montenegro}} {{Media of Montenegro}} {{Montenegrin First League top scorers |state=expanded}} [[Category:Radio stations in Montenegro]] [[Category:Media in Podgorica]] {{Europe-radio-station-stub}} {{montenegro-media-stub}}

Mikołaja]] |cocathedral = |area_km2 = 9,495 |population = 471,200 |population_as_of = 2013 |catholics = 451,000 |catholics_percent= 95.7 |pope = {{Incumbent pope}} |bishop = [[Jacek Jezierski (bishop)|Jacek Jezierski]] |metro_archbishop = [[Józef Górzyński]] |coadjutor = |auxiliary_bishops= | emeritus_bishops = Jan Styrna
Józef Wysocki | map = Mapa diecezji.jpg | map_size = 250px | map_alt = | map_caption = Map of the Diocese |website = [http://www.diecezja.elblag.opoka.org.pl/ Website of the Diocese] }} The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Elbląg''' ({{lang-la|Elbingen(sis)}}) is a [[diocese]] located in the city of [[Elbląg]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Warmia|Warmia]] in [[Poland]]. According to the Catholic Church statistics 28.4 % of the population went to church once a week in 2013 which was the lowest rank ever since 1980. ==History== * March 25, 1992: Established as Diocese of Elbląg from the [[Diocese of Chelmno]], [[Diocese of Gdańsk]] and Diocese of Warmia ==Leadership== *[[Bishop]]s of Elbląg (Roman rite) ** Bishop [[Jacek Jezierski (bishop)|Jacek Jezierski]] (since 2014.06.08) **Bishop [[Jan Styrna]] (2003.08.02 – 2014.05.10) **Bishop [[Andrzej Śliwiński]] (1992.03.25 – 2003.08.02) [[Image:Bp Jacek Jezierski.jpg|thumb|220px|left|Bishop Jacek Jezierski]] ==Special churches== * Former Cathedrals: ** Konkatedra św. Jana Chrzciciela w Kwidzynie, [[Kwidzyn]] ** Konkatedra św. Wojciecha, [[Prabuty]] ==See also== *[[Roman Catholicism in Poland]] ==Sources== * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/elbl0.htm GCatholic.org] * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/delbl.html Catholic Hierarchy] * [http://www.diecezja.elblag.opoka.org.pl/ Diocese website] {{Roman Catholic dioceses in Poland}} {{coord|54.1586|N|19.3955|E|source:wikidata-and-enwiki-cat-tree_region:PL|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Elblag}} [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses in Poland]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1992]] [[Category:Elbląg]] [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses and prelatures established in the 20th century]] {{Poland-stub}} {{Europe-RC-diocese-stub}}

{{Infobox language |name = Romano-Serbian |altname = Serbo-Romany |states = [[Serbia]] |speakers = {{sigfig|172,000|2}} |date = 2006 |ref=e18 |familycolor = mixed |family = [[mixed language|mixed]] [[Romani language|Romani]]–[[Serbian language|Serbian]] |iso3 = rsb |glotto=roma1241 |glottorefname=Romano-Serbian }}
The '''Romano-Serbian language''' is a [[mixed language]] (referred to as a [[Para-Romani]] variety in Romani linguistics) resulting from [[language contact]] between [[Serbian language|Serbian]] and [[Romani language|Romani]] in [[Serbia]] and [[Former Yugoslavia|former Yugoslav countries]] and distinct from the [[Vlax Romani language|Vlax Romani]] dialects spoken in Serbia.
==Publications== In October 2005 the first text on the grammar of the [[Romani language|Romani proper]] in Serbia was published by linguist [[Rajko Đurić]], titled ''Gramatika e Rromane čhibaki - Граматика ромског језика (Gramatika romskog jezika)''.
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.dundjer.co.rs/recnik/?site=en.wikipedia.org web serbian-romani dictionary]
{{Romani languages}} [[Category:South Slavic languages]] [[Category:Serbian language]] [[Category:Romani in Serbia]] [[Category:Romani language]] [[Category:Mixed languages]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Serbs of Slovakia |image = [[File:Коморанске шајке 1597.jpg|300px]]
Serbs in Komarno (1597) |population = '''3,600''' (estimate) |popplace = [[File:Coat of arms of Komárno.png|15px]] '''[[Komárno]]'''
[[File:Coat of Arms of Bratislava.svg|15px]] '''[[Bratislava]]''' |rels = [[Serbian Orthodox Church]] |related = [[South Slavs]] }} {{Serbs}} There is a small number of Serbs in [[Slovakia]], mostly located in the southern town of [[Komárno]], where they have been living since the 17th century.{{cite web|url=http://slovakheritage.org/Townsvill/komarnopride.htm|title=The Pride of Komarno|publisher=}} There has also been a historic minority in [[Bratislava]] ([[Požun]]), where many Habsburg Serbs studied. The number of Slovaks of Serb descent is hard to determine but nevertheless they are recognized as an official [[ethnic minority|minority]].{{cite web|url=http://www.balkans.com/open-news.php?uniquenumber=47069}} ==Demographics== [[File:Komárom24.JPG|thumb|left|150px|Serbian church in [[Komárno]]]] The Association of Serbs in Slovakia claim that 2,784 Serbs, born outside Slovakia, currently live in Slovakia, while another 800 Slovaks are of Serb descent.{{sfn|Lopušina|2014|loc= "U Slovačkoj se, prema policijskim podacima momentalno nalazi 2.784 naših ljudi, koji su tu zbog spajanja rodbine, studiranja, rada ili nekog drugog razloga i još 800 ljudi srpskog porekla - tvrdi Stane Ribič, predsednik udruženja Srba u Slovačkoj."}} According to the 2011 census, there were 698 Serbian nationals in Slovakia.{{cite web|url=http://slovak.statistics.sk/wps/wcm/connect/bd447dc5-c417-48d6-89e1-0a2d60053cf6/Table_10_Population_by_nationality_2011_2001_1991.pdf?MOD=AJPERES|title=Štatistický úrad SR - Úvodná stránka|publisher=}} ==Notable people== *[[Branko Radivojevic]], Slovak ice hockey player of Serb parentage *[[Marko Milinkovic]], Serbian expatriate football player *[[Martin Tešovič]], Slovak weightlifter of possible Serb origin. *[[Marek Krajčovič]] Slovak sprint canoeist of possible Serb origin. *[[Slaven Dizdarević]] Slovak Serb decathlete. *[[Mário Filipovič]] Slovak sport shooter of possible Serb origin. *[[Miroslav Machovič]] Slovak swimmer of possible Serb origin. *[[Gavril Stefanović Venclović]] Serb priest, writer, poet, orator, philosopher, and illuminator. *[[Paul Davidovich|Pavle Davidović]] Serb general, Knight of the [[Military Order of Maria Theresa]]. *[[Igor Matovič]] Slovak politician of possible Serb origin. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Sources== *{{cite web|last=Cerović|first=Ljubivoje|title=Srbi u Slovačkoj|year=1997|publisher=Ministarstvo Republike Srbije za veze sa Srbima izvan Srbije|url=http://www.rastko.rs/antropologija/ljcerovic_srbi_slv.html}} {{sr icon}} *{{cite book|last=Cerović|first=Ljubivoje|title=Srbi na Slovensku|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i9QlAAAAMAAJ|year=1999|publisher=Kultúra}} {{sk icon}} *[http://www.novosti.rs/vesti/planeta.301.html:489936-Svaki-drugi-Srbin-zivi-izvan-Srbije Svaki drugi Srbin zivi izvan Srbije] {{Ethnic groups in Slovakia}} {{Serbian diaspora}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Serbs of Slovakia}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Slovakia]] [[Category:Serbian diaspora in Europe|Slovakia]] [[Category:Serbs of Slovakia| ]] [[Category:Serb minorities|Slovakia]] [[Category:Slovak people of Serbian descent| ]] {{Serbia-stub}} {{Slovakia-stub}}

'''Sofare''': his name is from '''Société de Fabrication de Rétrochargeurs''' or '''Company Manufacturing backhoe loaders''' a subsidiary of the [[ENMTP]], with a registered capital of 2 billion DZD specialized in manufacturing backhoe loaders, Compaction Equipment,Stationary Compressors and Concrete injection pump.
==Partnership== The SOFARE developed compactors of New Generation products through its subsidiary [[Europactor Algeria]] created as a joint venture, in partnership with the Spanish company Europactor Aaecomhel.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.enmtp.com/europactor-algerie-3/|title=Europactor Algérie {{!}} ENMTP – Un partenaire avec vous & pour vous|website=www.enmtp.com|language=fr-FR|access-date=2017-09-07}}</ref>
==Products== The current line of products manufactured by the company includes:
=== Backhoe loaders=== *[[ENMTP 4120 S]] *[[ENMTP 4130]] *[[ENMTP 4140 B]] 2x4 *[[ENMTP 4150]] 4x4
=== Compaction Equipment === * Vibrating plates: BP 18 * Single drum compactors: '''SP 24''' and '''SP 54''' * Double drum compactor: '''DA 30'''
=== Stationary Compressors (Electric/Diesel)=== *D 24 *D 45 *D 71 *D 103 *E 28 *E 92 *CE 93
=== Concrete pumps=== * MI 25
and other small & medium constructions machines.
